children.subject:
Thanks for clarifying that. Have you found concepts/ideas from 168 especially useful in any interviews for internships/full-time? And were the projects difficult to do well on or just boring/tedious?

For what it's worth I can possibly fit both into my schedule eventually, but I'm just wondering if there will be any added benefit

to doing so as opposed to either diversifying into other interesting non-major courses or delving into a grad course or two. I will definitely be taking 162 at some point in time.

By the time I took 168 I had already secured a job in an unrelated field so I can’t comment on that. However, one of the TAs was saying that some of our exam questions were verbatim questions he had received in interviews.

Project specs basically told you what to do line by line which felt orthogonal to the design-thinking emphasized in lecture. Granted, coming up with these projects is difficult so I appreciate what the staff provided for us.

In general, don’t expect classes to help you prepare for interviews. Interview questions are like the SAT. You just grind meaningless practice problems and hope you can pattern match your way through the real thing.

I'm not really in the systems or networking fields, but 168 is the class that taught me about design and architecture of anything related to computers/programming. Even if most of these lessons are taught in a networking/internet architecture context, I found they are pretty applicable to even writing everyday programs.

While I already had a job prior to taking 168, I can definitely attest that the things we learned in 168 are very applicable and highly likely to come up in a web-dev interview. 

161 teaches a lot of common sense concepts, and how to hack, essentially. It’s a lot of fun (though much, much, much more time consuming that 168). Personally I prefer 168

Haven’t taken 161 but I can comment on 168.

If you’re planning to work in web dev, 168 will give you a practical overview of internet architecture concepts and protocols. But more importantly, it goes into the “why” of specific designs whereas most classes in Berkeley go into the “how”. Asking why certain designs work provide a more reproducible toolset that can be applied to any engineering problem. Scott did a great job of making this toolset very apparent. I wasn’t a fan of any of the projects, though.

I’ve heard some great things about 161 as well so this might be a tough decision. I personally believe 162 is the most important SWE class.

history.content: I took both this semester. If you're forcing yourself to take one, take 161. Security is more ubiquitous and is integral to every piece of code you write in your future, no matter the field. Networks, not so much. Although taking 168 with Scott helps you learn about architecting real-world systems in the networking context, so if that's something you see yourself doing, you should take it.

Are either of these courses worth taking, from an industry (SWE) point of view? Given a strict choice between the two, which one would be more useful/applicable to a larger extent? Any information/thoughts about these courses would be appreciated!
history.subject: CS 161/168
